questions.text: In the setting of suspected disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which laboratory finding is most indicative of the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased Fibrin Degradation Products (FDPs)

 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is characterized by widespread activation of coagulation, leading to the formation of thrombi in small vessels throughout the body, and consequent ischemia.
  • The consumption of clotting factors and platelets leads to bleeding.
  • The increased fibrin degradation products (also known as fibrin split products, which include D-dimer) are a hallmark of DIC, reflecting the high turnover of fibrin due to both ongoing coagulation and fibrinolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased PT (Prothrombin Time): While an increased PT may be seen in DIC, it is not as specific as the presence of increased FDPs.

 

Option B. Increased aPTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time): Increased aPTT is also common in DIC but again is less specific than increased FDPs.

 

Option C. Decreased fibrinogen: Decreased fibrinogen levels are another finding in DIC but are less specific than increased FDPs, which are directly indicative of the breakdown of fibrin clots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The increased fibrin degradation products, including D-dimer, are indicative of DIC, as they reflect the body's response to widespread clotting and subsequent fibrinolysis.
  • Testing for FDPs is critical in the diagnosis and monitoring of DIC.

choices.text: Used for treatment of advanced breast cancer
Is slower and short acting and less safe than SERMs
Administered as once a month i.m. dose

questions.text: Which statement is NOT true regarding the selective estrogen receptor down-regulator (SERD), Fulvestrant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Is slower and short acting and less safe than SERMs

 

  • Fulvestrant, a selective estrogen receptor down-regulator (SERD), is known for being a long-acting estrogen antagonist with no agonist effects, making it effective for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer.
  • Contrary to the statement in option C, Fulvestrant is neither short-acting nor less safe than selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs); it is actually designed for long-lasting effect and is typically administered once a month by intramuscular injection, reflecting its prolonged action.
  • Safety profiles may vary, but it is not inherently less safe than SERMs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Used for treatment of advanced breast cancer: True, Fulvestrant is indeed used for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women.

 

Option B. Is a selective estrogen antagonist: True, it acts as a selective estrogen antagonist, binding, and degrading estrogen receptors.

 

Option D. Administered as once a month i.m. dose: True, it is administered as a once-a-month intramuscular dose which reflects its long-lasting effect in the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Unlike SERMs, which may have partial estrogen agonist effects, SERDs like Fulvestrant provide a strong and consistent estrogen-blocking action, useful particularly in cases where estrogen promotes the growth of cancerous cells.

questions.text: An hour after a normal vaginal delivery, a newborn is observed to have decreased respiratory effort and reduced responsiveness in the neonatal ward. The mother received analgesia during labor. Which of the following drugs administered to the mother is most likely responsible for the newborn's respiratory depression?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Opioids

 

  • Opioids like fentanyl, when used for analgesia during labor, can cross the placental barrier and cause respiratory depression in the newborn.
  • Opioid effects on neonates include reduced respiratory drive and decreased responsiveness.
  • Nalbuphine is another opioid that can cause similar effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barbiturates: While these can cause CNS depression, they are less commonly used for labor analgesia and are less likely to cause acute neonatal respiratory depression immediately post-delivery.

 

Option C. Diazepam: This benzodiazepine can cause sedation in neonates but is more commonly associated with hypotonia and a "floppy baby syndrome" rather than profound respiratory depression.

 

Option D. Propofol: This is an intravenous anesthetic agent not typically used for labor analgesia and is unlikely to be the cause in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epidural opioid (Fentanyl) analgesia is commonly given as a therapeutic modality in management of pain during labour.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a history of weakness and fatigue for the past three months. There is no history of alcohol consumption or intake of any drugs. A complete blood count and peripheral smear show evidence of megaloblastic anemia and a normal reticulocyte count. He is found to have vitamin B12 deficiency on further laboratory testing. What is the most likely cause of anemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autoimmune gastritis

 

  • The most likely cause of the vitamin B12 deficiency in this patient is autoimmune gastritis. This condition involves chronic inflammation of the stomach mucosa, which leads to the destruction of parietal cells that are responsible for the secretion of intrinsic factor.
  • Intrinsic factor is crucial for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. Without adequate intrinsic factor, vitamin B12 cannot be absorbed, leading to deficiency and the subsequent development of megaloblastic anemia, as evidenced by the patient's blood tests.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ménétrier disease: This condition primarily affects the stomach's mucosa, leading to excessive mucous secretion and protein loss. It does not typically result in vitamin B12 deficiency, which is central to this patient's presentation.

 

Option C. Helicobacter pylori gastritis: While H. pylori infection can lead to chronic gastritis and is a common cause of gastritis worldwide, it is less likely to cause vitamin B12 deficiency directly compared to autoimmune gastritis, as H. pylori primarily affects the antrum and less so the body where parietal cells are predominantly located.

 

Option D. Acute erosive gastritis: This condition involves the erosion of the stomach lining due to various causes like medications or stress but does not typically lead to chronic issues such as vitamin B12 deficiency unless associated with prolonged and severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with megaloblastic anemia and vitamin B12 deficiency without a history of alcohol or drug intake, the most likely cause is autoimmune gastritis, where the destruction of parietal cells prevents the secretion of intrinsic factor necessary for vitamin B12 absorption.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with symptoms of polyuria, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status has been diagnosed with bronchogenic carcinoma. What electrolyte abnormality is most commonly associated with this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypercalcemia

 

  • Bronchogenic carcinoma, particularly squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, can lead to a paraneoplastic syndrome resulting in hypercalcemia.
  • This occurs due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) by the tumor, which mimics the action of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and leads to increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys and mobilization of calcium from bones.
  • The symptoms of polyuria, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status can all be manifestations of hypercalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: Hypokalemia can be seen in various conditions but is not typically associated with bronchogenic carcinoma.

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia is commonly associated with renal failure or conditions affecting potassium balance but is not the primary electrolyte abnormality expected in bronchogenic carcinoma.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia is not typically associated with bronchogenic carcinoma and does not fit the clinical picture presented.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bronchogenic carcinoma is due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) by the tumor, which leads to increased serum calcium levels.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with unsteady gait and slurred speech. On neurological examination, he demonstrates dysmetria, intention tremor, and dysarthria. Imaging reveals cerebellar atrophy. Dysfunction of which of the following nuclei receiving inhibitory input from Purkinje cells in the cerebellum is most likely contributing to his symptoms among given options?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fastigial Nucleus

 

  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory to all deep cerebellar nuclei- dentate, emboliform, globose and fastigial nucleus. They also project to all vestibular nuclei.
  • Purkinje cells project inhibitory signals to the fastigial nucleus. This projection is a key part of the cerebellar circuitry that influences motor control and balance.
  • The output from the fastigial nucleus is crucial for postural adjustments and control of muscle tone, as part of the integrated motor control system.

 

OTHER OPTIONS:

 

Option A. Arcuate Nucleus: Arcuate Nucleus is a collection of neurons in the hypothalamus, involved in releasing hormones that regulate pituitary function. There is no direct connection between Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and the arcuate nucleus. The primary function of the arcuate nucleus is in the endocrine system, not in the motor control or coordination associated with cerebellar functions.

 

Option C. Superior Olivary Nucleus: Superior Olivary Nucleus is involved in auditory processing, particularly in localizing sound in the brainstem. Purkinje cells do not project directly to the superior olivary nucleus. The cerebellum and the superior olivary complex serve different functions; the former in motor control and the latter in auditory processing.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral Thalamic Nucleus: Ventral Lateral Thalamic Nucleus is a part of the thalamus involved in motor functions. While the cerebellum does communicate with the thalamus, particularly in the context of motor coordination, Purkinje cells specifically do not project directly to the ventral lateral thalamic nucleus. Instead, the output from cerebellar nuclei (including the fastigial nucleus) reaches the thalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The output from the fastigial nucleus is crucial for postural adjustments and control of muscle tone, as part of the integrated motor control system.

choices.text: Symptomatic patients present with cough, expectoration, fever, and haemoptysis
Capitonnage is done for pulmonary hydatids
Meniscus sign implies impending rupture of cyst

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about pulmonary hydatid cyst disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medical management is the mainstay.

 

The mainstay of treatment of pulmonary hydatid is surgery. Medical treatments are less successful and considered when surgery is not possible because of poor general condition or diffuse disease affecting both lungs, or recurrent or ruptured cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symptomatic patients present with cough, expectoration, fever, and haemoptysis: This is a correct statement. Symptomatic patients with pulmonary hydatid cyst disease can present with these respiratory symptoms as the cysts in the lungs cause irritation and inflammation.

 

Option B. Capitonnage is done for pulmonary hydatids: Capitonnage is a surgical technique used in the treatment of pulmonary hydatid disease. It involves the obliteration of the residual cavity after the removal of a hydatid cyst to prevent space problems and secondary infection. This is a correct statement.

 

Option C. Meniscus sign implies impending rupture of cyst: The meniscus or crescent sign refers to the appearance of air between the pericyst and the ectocyst of a hydatid cyst on imaging studies. It can indicate that the cyst is under tension and may be at risk of rupture. This statement is also correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary treatment for pulmonary hydatid cyst disease is surgical resection, with medical management playing a secondary role, often when surgery is not possible due to the patient's condition or when the disease is too diffuse.Top of Form

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with Parkinsonism presents with swollen, red, tender, and very painful feet. Which medication, if discontinued, could likely resolve these symptoms within a few days?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amantadine

 

  • Amantadine, commonly used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease, can cause livedo reticularis and peripheral edema as side effects.
  • These symptoms manifest as mottling of the skin, often accompanied by swelling and pain in the extremities, particularly in the lower legs and feet.
  • Discontinuing amantadine often leads to a rapid resolution of these side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benztropine: Benztropine is an anticholinergic agent used in Parkinsonism to reduce tremor and rigidity but is not typically associated with causing swollen, tender, and painful feet.

 

Option C. Bromocriptine: Bromocriptine, a dopamine agonist, can have many side effects, but causing painful, swollen feet directly is not characteristically one of them.

 

Option D. Levodopa: Levodopa is the most effective drug for Parkinson's disease and can cause dyskinesias and other motor complications but does not typically cause the described symptoms of painful, swollen feet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The side effects associated with Parkinson's disease medications, particularly amantadine can cause livedo reticularis and peripheral edema.

questions.text: A previously healthy 10-month-old male infant suddenly becomes irritable and distressed while in his crib. On physical examination, the external genitalia appear normal but exhibit notable hyperpigmentation. Laboratory tests reveal a blood glucose level of 30 mg/dL. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Familial glucocorticoid deficiency

 

  • Familial glucocorticoid deficiency (FGD) is characterized by primary adrenal insufficiency without mineralocorticoid deficiency.
  • The hallmark of this condition is adrenal hyperplasia with low cortisol levels leading to hypoglycemia and hyperpigmentation due to the increased production of ACTH, which shares a precursor with melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH).
  • FGD typically presents in infancy or early childhood with symptoms of glucocorticoid deficiency, such as hypoglycemia, seizures, and shock, but without abnormalities in genitalia or blood pressure abnormalities, as the mineralocorticoid function is preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 21-hydroxylase deficiency: This condition usually presents with salt wasting and/or virilization due to excess androgen production, which does not align with the normal genitalia described in the scenario.

 

Option B. Hyperinsulinism: Causes hypoglycemia but is not associated with hyperpigmentation of the skin.

 

Option D. Cushing's syndrome: It is characterized by an excess of cortisol and features such as weight gain, moon face, and striae, not hypoglycemia and hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Familial glucocorticoid deficiency
    • Familial glucocorticoid deficiency is a rare autosomal recessive condition.
    • It is characterized by adrenal insufficiency.
    • The pathological examination of the adrenal gland reveals that: -
      • Zona glomerulosa → well preserved
      • Zona fasciculata → atrophied
      • Zona reticularis → atrophied

 

This causes low cortisol concentration because the zona fasciculata is primarily responsible for glucocorticoid production. Because the zona glomerulosa is well preserved mineralocorticoid action is usually unaffected. Low circulating serum cortisol results in lack of feedback inhibition to the hypothalamus which results in increased ACTH secretion from pituitary.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man undergoes a rectal examination during which a hard, irregular prostate nodule is detected. A biopsy sample taken from the nodule shows crowded small glands that are lined by a single layer of cells with prominent, enlarged nucleoli. Further immunohistochemical analysis reveals no outer basal cell layer in the glands. Which area of the prostate is most likely the origin of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripheral zone

 

  • The description of the biopsy indicating crowded small glands lined by a single layer of cells with enlarged, prominent nucleoli and the absence of an outer basal cell layer is characteristic of prostate adenocarcinoma.
  • The majority of prostate adenocarcinomas (about 70-80%) originate in the peripheral zone of the prostate.
  • This zone is the most likely area to develop these cancers, partially because it is the largest region and most accessible via rectal examination, where such nodules are often first detected.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Anterior zone: This area of the prostate is less commonly affected by adenocarcinoma. Lesions in this zone are usually harder to detect by rectal examination because of their location at the front of the prostate gland.

 

Option B. Central zone: Cancers originating from this zone are quite rare and account for a very small percentage of all prostate cancers. The central zone is situated around the ejaculatory ducts, and cancers in this area are less commonly detected early by rectal examination.

 

Option D. Transition zone: Although cancers can arise in this zone, they are typically associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) rather than adenocarcinoma. Transition zone tumors account for a smaller fraction of prostate cancers compared to those originating in the peripheral zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prostate adenocarcinomas most commonly originate from the peripheral zone of the prostate, characterized by abnormalities detectable in a biopsy such as crowded glandular architecture, prominent nucleoli, and absence of the basal cell layer.
  • This zone is also the most accessible for detection during a rectal examination, explaining the commonality of finding such lesions in this area.

choices.text: Corticosteroids facilitate the action of β2 agonists
Corticosteroids sensitize adenosine receptors to xanthines

questions.text: A patient with a history of asthma presents to the emergency department in severe respiratory distress that has not responded to short-acting beta-agonists like salbutamol. Corticosteroids and aminophylline have been administered. What is the rationale for using corticosteroids in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids facilitate the action of β2 agonists

 

  • Corticosteroids are administered in acute asthma exacerbations to reduce airway inflammation.
  • While they do not have direct bronchodilator effects, corticosteroids enhance the responsiveness of β2 agonists, making them more effective.
  • This is achieved through the upregulation of β2 receptors and a reduction in airway inflammation, leading to decreased airway hyperresponsiveness.
  • The beneficial effects of corticosteroids in acute asthma management include decreased edema, reduced mucus production, and inhibition of inflammatory cell migration and activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticosteroids sensitize adenosine receptors to xanthines: Corticosteroids do not sensitize adenosine receptors to xanthines; aminophylline works by inhibiting phosphodiesterase, leading to an increase in cAMP and bronchodilation.

 

Option C. Direct bronchodilator action of corticosteroids: Corticosteroids do not have a direct bronchodilatory effect; their primary action is anti-inflammatory.

 

Option D. Increase mucociliary clearance: While corticosteroids may help reduce mucus production in chronic management, increasing mucociliary clearance is not the primary rationale for their use in acute asthma exacerbations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Corticosteroids are used in acute asthma exacerbations to potentiate the effects of β2 agonists by reducing airway inflammation and upregulating β2 receptors, rather than providing direct bronchodilation.
  • This mechanism is crucial for the effective management of severe asthma attacks.

choices.text: Upper division of III nerve
Lower division of III nerve

questions.text: Nerve supply to the pointed structure:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lower division of III nerve

 

  • Pointed structure is medial rectus in the medial wall of orbit below the superior oblique muscle. It is innervated by Lower division of III nerve.
  • The lower division of the oculomotor nerve (III) innervates the inferior oblique muscle, along with the medial rectus, inferior rectus, and the pupillary sphincter muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trochlear nerve: The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for depression and intorsion of the eyeball, particularly when it is adducted.

 

Option B. Upper division of III nerve: Upper division of III nerve The upper division of the oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris and the superior rectus muscle.

 

Option D. Abducens nerve: The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by the lower division of the oculomotor nerve.
  • Understanding the innervation is important for diagnosing and treating conditions that affect eye movement and positioning.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient presents with a 4 cm diameter breast cancer lesion and ipsilateral axillary as well as contralateral supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. According to the AJCC staging system, to which stage of breast cancer does this patient belong?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV

 

 

Stage IV breast cancer indicates the presence of distant metastasis. According to the AJCC staging system, metastasis to the contralateral supraclavicular lymph nodes is classified as distant metastasis, which places this patient in Stage IV.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. IIIa: This stage does not apply because it suggests no distant metastasis but rather involvement of axillary lymph nodes or breast size, without mention of contralateral lymph node involvement.

 

Option B. IIIb: This stage involves the breast and skin or chest wall, including inflammatory breast cancer, without distant metastasis.

 

Option C. IIIc: This stage involves more extensive regional lymph node involvement but still without distant metastasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In breast cancer staging, the involvement of contralateral supraclavicular lymph nodes is indicative of Stage IV disease, representing distant metastasis.
  • It is crucial to differentiate local and regional lymph node involvement from distant metastasis for accurate staging and management of breast cancer.

questions.text: Naltrexone is used to maintain abstinence following opioid withdrawal in addicts. It blocks all of the following features of opioid use, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Craving for opioids

 

  • Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that works by blocking opioid receptors, which prevents the euphoriant effects of opioids, mitigates respiratory depression, and prevents miosis associated with opioid use.
  • However, while naltrexone effectively blocks the physiological effects of opioids, it does not directly reduce the psychological craving for opioids.
  • Craving is a complex phenomenon influenced by many psychological and environmental factors and requires additional therapeutic approaches such as counseling and support groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Euphoriant effects of opioids: The euphoriant effects of opioids are blocked by naltrexone, as it prevents opioids from binding to their receptors.

 

Option C. Miosis: Miosis, or pinpoint pupils, is a common effect of opioid use. Naltrexone blocks the action of opioids at their receptors, which includes preventing miosis.

 

Option D. Respiratory depression: Respiratory depression, a dangerous effect of opioid overdose, is also prevented by naltrexone due to its action as an opioid receptor antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Naltrexone helps in maintaining abstinence by blocking the effects of opioids at their receptor sites but does not address opioid craving directly, highlighting the need for comprehensive addiction treatment programs that include both pharmacological and psychological support.

choices.text: Greater potential to block a resting nerve as compared to a stimulated nerve
Need to cross the cell membrane to produce the block
Large myelinated fibers are blocked before the unmyelinated fibers
Cause consistent change of resting membrane potential

questions.text: Blockade of nerve conduction by a local anesthetic is characterized by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Need to cross the cell membrane to produce the block

 

  • Local anesthetics work by entering the nerve cells and binding to the voltage-gated sodium channels from the inside (intracellularly), which blocks these channels and prevents nerve conduction.
  • This process requires the local anesthetic molecules to cross the cell membrane to reach their site of action inside the nerve cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Greater potential to block a resting nerve as compared to a stimulated nerve: This statement is incorrect as local anesthetics are more effective in blocking nerves that are frequently stimulated, not resting nerves. Frequently stimulated nerves are more likely to have a higher proportion of sodium channels in states that are more susceptible to blockade.

 

Option C. Large myelinated fibers are blocked before the unmyelinated fibers: This statement is also incorrect. Typically, smaller and unmyelinated fibers are more susceptible to blockade by local anesthetics before larger, myelinated fibers. The thickness of the myelin sheath and the size of the nerve affect the diffusion of the anesthetic, making smaller, unmyelinated fibers easier to block.

 

Option D. Cause consistent change of resting membrane potential: Local anesthetics do not cause a consistent change in the resting membrane potential; rather, they block the transient increase in membrane permeability to sodium ions, which is necessary for action potential generation and propagation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Local anesthetics must cross the cell membrane to access and inhibit the intracellular portion of sodium channels, effectively preventing the conduction of nerve impulses.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is seen for a routine antenatal visit. She has a history of bipolar disorder and is concerned about the potential teratogenic effects of her medications on the fetus. She recalls being specifically warned about the risk of congenital heart defects with one of the medications. Which substance, if taken during pregnancy, is most commonly associated with the development of Ebstein's anomaly in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lithium

 

  • Ebstein's anomaly is a rare heart defect in which the tricuspid valve is abnormally formed. It has been associated with maternal use of lithium during the first trimester of pregnancy.
  • Lithium is used in the management of bipolar disorder and carries a risk of congenital heart defects, including Ebstein's anomaly, if taken during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mercury: Exposure to mercury in pregnancy can cause a range of developmental disorders and congenital abnormalities, but it is not specifically linked to Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Option B. Copper: There is no well-established link between maternal copper intake and Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead exposure can lead to a variety of fetal developmental issues, but it is not specifically associated with Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • There is the association between maternal lithium use during pregnancy and the risk of the fetus developing Ebstein's anomaly, a specific type of congenital heart defect.
  • Pregnant women taking lithium should be counselled about this risk and managed accordingly.

choices.text: Diffuse thickening of the GBM with a spike and dome pattern
Tram-track appearance of the GBM

questions.text: A 39-year-old man, who was recently found to have renal vein thrombosis, is under medical review. His medical history includes significant weight gain, generalized edema, and hypertension. His urine analysis reveals significant proteinuria and the presence of numerous normal-looking red blood cells without any casts. Tests also show positive anti-PLA2R antibodies. Based on these findings, what would you expect to see on his renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diffuse thickening of the GBM with spike and dome pattern

 

  • The presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies is highly suggestive of primary membranous nephropathy.
  • This autoimmune disorder is characterized histologically by diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) due to subepithelial immune deposits.
  • These deposits can lead to the formation of a "spike and dome" pattern on silver staining of the renal biopsy, which is a classic finding in this condition.
  • The combination of gross proteinuria and the specific antibody presence further supports this diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tram-track appearance of the GBM: This finding is typical of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), which is associated with immune complex deposition and complement activation within the GBM and mesangium. It is not indicative of membranous nephropathy.

 

Option C. Mesangial deposition of IgA: The presence of IgA in the mesangium is characteristic of IgA nephropathy (Berger’s disease), which does not correlate with the presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies and is differentiated by its immunofluorescence staining patterns.

 

Option D. Large and hypercellular glomeruli: This description fits with proliferative forms of glomerulonephritis, such as lupus nephritis or acute post-infectious glomerulonephritis, rather than membranous nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient presenting with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome and testing positive for anti-PLA2R antibodies, the expected finding on renal biopsy is a diffuse thickening of the GBM with a spike and dome pattern, indicative of primary membranous nephropathy.

questions.text: A patient reports vomiting approximately 500 ml of blood. On physical examination, splenomegaly is noted, with the spleen being palpable 5 cm below the left costal margin. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Portal Hypertension

 

  • The combination of hematemesis and palpable splenomegaly strongly suggests portal hypertension as the most likely diagnosis.
  • Portal hypertension can lead to the development of varices in the gastrointestinal tract, which are prone to rupture and can cause significant bleeding as seen in this patient.
  • Splenomegaly is often present due to the increased pressure in the portal venous system and congestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gastric ulcer: Gastric ulcer could cause hematemesis, but it does not typically cause splenomegaly.

 

Option C. Drug induced: Drug-induced vomiting could lead to a Mallory Weiss tear, which might cause bleeding, but would not explain the splenomegaly.

 

Option D. Mallory Weiss Tear: Mallory Weiss Tear typically results from severe retching or vomiting, leading to a tear at the gastroesophageal junction, and while it could cause hematemesis, it would not be associated with splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary learning point from this scenario is that the presence of both hematemesis and splenomegaly should raise suspicion for portal hypertension, which can cause variceal bleeding, a potentially life-threatening emergency.

questions.text:
Spinal accessory nerve related to which of the following triangles:

 

  1. Occipital triangle
  2. Subclavian triangle
  3. Muscular triangle
  4. Carotid triangle
  5. Submental triangle
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,4

 

The spinal accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) passes through two primary triangles in the neck:

 

1. The occipital triangle, which is a part of the posterior triangle of the neck, bordered by the sternocleidomastoid muscle anteriorly, the trapezius muscle posteriorly, and the inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle inferiorly. The spinal accessory nerve travels superficially across the occipital triangle as it innervates the trapezius muscle.

 

4. The carotid triangle, which is a part of the anterior triangle of the neck, bordered by the sternocleidomastoid muscle posteriorly, the superior belly of the omohyoid muscle inferiorly, and the posterior digastric muscle superiorly. After emerging from the jugular foramen, the spinal accessory nerve crosses the carotid triangle deep to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, which it also innervates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1,2: The subclavian triangle (also known as the supraclavicular or omoclavicular triangle) is not one of the primary triangles through which the spinal accessory nerve passes.

 

Option B. 2,4: While the nerve crosses the carotid triangle, it does not pass through the subclavian triangle as part of its typical anatomical route.

 

Option D. 3,5: The muscular triangle and submental triangle are not associated with the course of the spinal accessory nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The spinal accessory nerve traverses the occipital and carotid triangles of the neck.

questions.text: Identify the likely pathology from the thyroid scan pattern shown in the figure:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypersecreting adenoma

 

  • The thyroid scan shows increased focal uptake in the right upper lobe of the thyroid and decreased uptake in the rest of the thyroid gland.
  • This pattern is suggestive of a hypersecreting thyroid adenoma.
  • Hypersecreting adenomas release increased levels of thyroid hormones (T3/T4), which leads to the suppression of TSH.
  • As a result, the rest of the thyroid gland becomes hypo-functional and exhibits decreased uptake in the scan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cold nodule: Cold nodule is characterized by low uptake in a given part in the thyroid scan due to reduced thyroid function in the nodule, which does not match the pattern seen in the image.

 

Option C. Grave’s disease: Graves disease typically presents with diffusely increased uptake throughout the gland due to generalized overactivity, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Aberrant/Ectopic Thyroid: Aberrant/Ectopic Thyroid tissue would show uptake outside of the normal thyroid location, which is not demonstrated in this scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A thyroid scan demonstrating a localized area of increased uptake with suppression of the rest of the gland is indicative of a hypersecreting adenoma.
  • This is a key finding and assists in the diagnosis of hyperthyroid pathologies within the gland.

questions.text: A young woman undergoing treatment for acute promyelocytic leukemia presents with sudden onset of fever, difficulty breathing, and radiographic evidence of pulmonary infiltrates. Considering the potential complications of her treatment, what is the most appropriate therapeutic intervention to manage her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dexamethasone

 

  • The scenario described suggests the development of differentiation syndrome, which can occur in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) being treated with agents such as all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) or arsenic trioxide.
  • Differentiation syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by fever, respiratory distress, pulmonary infiltrates, and other symptoms.
  • The treatment of choice is the administration of high-dose corticosteroids, such as dexamethasone, which can rapidly alleviate symptoms and improve outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cytarabine: While cytarabine is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of various leukemias, it is not the treatment of choice for differentiation syndrome in APL.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin: Doxorubicin is an anthracycline chemotherapeutic used in leukemia treatment, but it is not specifically used to treat differentiation syndrome.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic and immunosuppressant drug, but it is not the treatment for differentiation syndrome associated with APL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia undergoing treatment, the occurrence of differentiation syndrome is a serious and emergent complication and promptly initiating treatment with dexamethasone is critical for managing this syndrome effectively.

questions.text: A 20-month-old child presents to the clinic with a history of irritability and reluctance to walk for the past two weeks. The mother reports that the child has a poor diet, predominantly carbohydrate-based, with a significant lack of fruits and vegetables. On examination, the child appears in pain when moving the lower extremities and refuses to bear weight. There is noticeable swelling around the knees and wrists. Blood tests show a normal alkaline phosphatase level. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the observed pseudoparalysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scurvy

 

  • Pseudoparalysis, or apparent paralysis due to extreme pain on movement rather than actual loss of motor function, is a classic sign of scurvy, which is a vitamin C deficiency.
  • This condition is common in children with a diet deficient in fresh fruits and vegetables.
  • Scurvy leads to defective collagen synthesis, resulting in bone pain, swelling, and subperiosteal hemorrhages, which can present as pseudoparalysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rickets: While rickets can cause bone pain and deformities due to vitamin D deficiency, it is typically associated with elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, unlike what is presented in this scenario.

 

Option C. Polio: Poliomyelitis can cause actual paralysis due to motor neuron damage, but it would not typically cause joint swelling or be related to dietary deficiencies.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia is the softening of bones due to vitamin D or phosphate deficiency but occurs in adults, and the clinical presentation would not typically include pseudoparalysis in a child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scurvy is a cause of pseudoparalysis in children, which is linked to dietary vitamin C deficiency and can be identified by the clinical presentation of pain on movement, swelling in the joints, and a lack of hematological abnormalities such as elevated alkaline phosphatase.

choices.text: Infarct myocardium appears brick red due to loss of LDH activity
Viable myocardium appears brick red due to preserved LDH activity
Infarct myocardium appears unstained due to preserved LDH activity
Viable myocardium appears unstained due to the loss of LDH activity

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to his left arm was admitted to the emergency department. An ECG confirmed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. The patient passed away three hours later. During the autopsy, the heart was immersed in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. Which of the following statements about the outcome of this staining is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Viable myocardium appears brick red due to preserved LDH activity

 

  • Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) is a chemical used in pathology to stain heart tissue during autopsies to identify areas of damage.
  • TTC is reduced to formazan, which is a brick red precipitate, in the presence of hydrogen ions released during the enzymatic reaction involving lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in viable myocardial cells.
  • Thus, areas where the myocardium is still viable and enzymatic activity is preserved will appear brick red. In contrast, areas of infarct myocardium, where the cells have died and enzyme activity is lost, do not reduce TTC and thus appear pale or unstained.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infarct myocardium appears brick red due to loss of LDH activity: This statement is incorrect because the loss of LDH activity in infarct myocardium prevents the reduction of TTC, and thus these areas do not stain red.

 

Option C. Infarct myocardium appears unstained due to preserved LDH activity: This statement is incorrect because it is in the infarcted areas where LDH activity is not preserved, resulting in no staining.

 

Option D. Viable myocardium appears unstained due to the loss of LDH activity: This statement is incorrect as the viable myocardium will show preserved LDH activity and thus will appear red due to the formation of formazan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the use of triphenyl tetrazolium chloride staining during autopsies, viable myocardium appears brick red due to preserved LDH activity, which allows the reduction of TTC to formazan, whereas infarct myocardium appears pale or unstained due to the loss of enzymatic activity.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presents with cirrhosis, skin hyperpigmentation, and restrictive cardiomyopathy. Which laboratory test should be performed first to aid in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Percent transferrin saturation

 

  • The combination of diabetes, cirrhosis, skin hyperpigmentation, and restrictive cardiomyopathy in this patient suggests hemochromatosis, a condition of iron overload.
  • The best initial test for hemochromatosis is percent transferrin saturation, which measures the amount of iron bound to transferrin, the main iron-transport protein.
  • An elevated percentage indicates that an excess of iron is being transported in the blood, which is typical in hemochromatosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum ferritin: Serum ferritin could also be elevated in hemochromatosis, as it is an acute phase reactant and an indicator of stored iron, but percent transferrin saturation is the preferred initial test.

 

Option C. Serum copper: Serum copper is used in the evaluation of Wilson's disease, which does not present with restrictive cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Serum ceruloplasmin: Serum ceruloplasmin is also a test for Wilson's disease, characterized by low serum ceruloplasmin levels, but Wilson's disease typically presents with neurological symptoms rather than restrictive cardiomyopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The percent transferrin saturation is the best initial test for suspected hemochromatosis, a disorder characterized by iron overload that can lead to diabetes, cirrhosis, skin hyperpigmentation, and cardiomyopathy.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent organ damage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with recurrent episodes of palpitations and dizziness. An echocardiogram reveals an enlarged right atrium and evidence of a right-to-left shunt. During the cardiac catheterization procedure, the cardiologist observes a valve-like structure within the right atrium. Which of the following structures guards the opening of the coronary sinus and may be contributing to the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thebesian Valve

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the patient is experiencing palpitations and dizziness, suggesting the possibility of an abnormal shunt within the heart.
  • The Thebesian valve, also known as the valve of coronary sinus, is a structure within the right atrium that guards the opening of the coronary sinus.
  • If this valve is abnormally developed or functioning, it can potentially lead to right-to-left shunting of blood, causing symptoms like those described. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crista Terminalis: Crista terminalis is a smooth muscle ridge which extends from the upper part of the atrial septum to the right horn of the IVC valve.

 

Option C. Mitral Valve: Mitral valve guards the left atrioventricular orifice.

 

Option D. Eustachian Valve: The Eustachian valve guards the opening of IVC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Coronary sinus opening is situated in the lower part of interatrial septum and opening is guarded by thebesian valve.

questions.text: According to Barcelona clinic for liver cancer (BCLC), a patient with multi-lobular liver cancer with good performance status and Child’s A disease should be managed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TACE (trans-arterial chemoembolization)

 

  • TACE is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with multinodular HCC (stage B) who do not have vascular invasion or extrahepatic spread and have preserved liver function (Child-Pugh A or B).
  • Given a patient with multi-lobular liver cancer, good performance status, and Child’s A disease, according to BCLC, the appropriate management would be TACE, assuming the patient falls into stage B of HCC, where the disease is more advanced than early-stage but has not yet reached the criteria for systemic therapy or best supportive care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide excision: Wide excision, or surgical resection, is typically recommended for patients with early-stage HCC (stage 0–A), who have a single tumor and good liver function, without evidence of vascular invasion or extrahepatic spread.

 

Option B. Liver Transplant: Liver transplantation is considered for patients with early-stage HCC (stage 0–A) who meet specific criteria, such as the Milan criteria (single HCC ≤ 5 cm or up to 3 nodules each ≤ 3 cm), and no evidence of extrahepatic disease or vascular invasion.

 

Option D. Sorafenib: Sorafenib is an oral tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for patients with advanced HCC (stage C) that has spread or cannot be treated with surgery or TACE. This is suitable for patients with vascular invasion or extrahepatic disease and good performance status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the BCLC staging system for HCC, patients with multinodular, non-early-stage tumors and preserved liver function (Child’s A) are typically managed with trans-arterial chemoembolization (TACE), reflecting a balance between therapeutic intervention and the patient’s liver function reserve.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with prolonged bleeding time, denies NSAID intake, and has no other significant drug history. Which of the following drugs is least likely to prolong bleeding time?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multivitamins containing Vitamin K

 

  • Multivitamins containing Vitamin K are least likely to prolong bleeding time.
  • Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of clotting factors, and its presence in a multivitamin would typically support the clotting cascade rather than inhibit it, thereby not prolonging the bleeding time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cephalosporins: Cephalosporins, particularly those with a methylthiotetrazole side chain (e.g., cefoperazone, cefamandole), can interfere with vitamin K metabolism and potentially prolong bleeding time by reducing the effectiveness of clotting factors.

 

Option C. Methylxanthines: Methylxanthines generally do not have a direct effect on bleeding time. They primarily act as bronchodilators and have stimulant effects but are not known for their impact on coagulation or bleeding parameters.

 

Option D. Anti-depressants: Certain antidepressants, especially SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), have been associated with an increased risk of bleeding, particularly gastrointestinal bleeding. They can affect platelet aggregation and prolong bleeding time.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Vitamins such as vitamin K contained in multivitamins would support the clotting process and thus not prolong bleeding time.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man has had increasing difficulty swallowing during the past 6 months. There are no significant findings on physical examination. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy shows areas of erythematous mucosa above the Z-line. A biopsy specimen from the lower esophagus has the microscopic appearance shown in the figure. Which of the following complications is most likely to occur as a consequence of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenocarcinoma

 

  • The biopsy specimen provided shows columnar epithelium in the lower esophagus, which is indicative of Barrett's esophagus, a condition that arises due to chronic acid reflux from the stomach into the esophagus.
  • Barrett's esophagus is characterized by the replacement of the normal stratified squamous epithelium with metaplastic columnar epithelium.
  • Patients with Barrett's esophagus are at an increased risk for developing esophageal adenocarcinoma due to the ongoing process of dysplasia that can occur in the metaplastic tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hematemesis: While hematemesis is a potential complication of esophageal lesions, there is no direct link in the question to suggest recent bleeding or a bleeding disorder, making this option less relevant than adenocarcinoma in the context of Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of carcinoma is more commonly associated with risk factors such as smoking and alcohol consumption and arises from the squamous epithelium, not the columnar epithelium seen in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option D. Achalasia: Achalasia is a motility disorder characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax and is not a complication of Barrett's esophagus, which is an epithelial change rather than a motility disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Barrett's esophagus is a condition characterized by the metaplastic change of the normal esophageal squamous epithelium to a columnar lining due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux, significantly increasing the risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is evaluated for symptoms of malabsorption and iron deficiency anemia. A duodenal biopsy reveals complete villous atrophy. Which antibody is most likely to be positive in this patient, aiding in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antiendomysial antibodies

 

  • The presence of complete villous atrophy on duodenal biopsy in a patient with features of malabsorption and iron deficiency anemia is highly suggestive of celiac disease.
  • Antiendomysial antibodies (EMA) are highly specific for celiac disease and would be the appropriate serologic test to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-goblet cell antibodies: Anti-goblet cell antibodies are not associated with a specific diagnosis and are not a recognized marker for celiac disease or other common causes of villous atrophy.

 

Option C. Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies: Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) are most commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease, particularly Crohn's disease, and not with celiac disease.

 

Option D. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are associated with vasculitis and inflammatory bowel diseases, such as ulcerative colitis, and are not typically linked to celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Antiendomysial antibodies are highly specific for celiac disease and should be tested in patients with malabsorption, iron deficiency anemia, and biopsy findings of complete villous atrophy.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male was brought to ER with complaints of profuse upper GI bleed. His past history couldn’t be obtained. His BP was 60/40 and his PR 140/min. Inspite of immediate resuscitation measures initiated, the patient failed to survive. Autopsy showed a deep peptic ulcer in the lesser curvature of stomach. Which of the following arteries would have been penetrated by the ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left gastric artery

 

  • A peptic ulcer located on the lesser curvature of the stomach is most likely to penetrate the left gastric artery.
  • This artery runs along the lesser curvature and is therefore at risk of being involved by a penetrating ulcer in this location.
  • Such involvement can lead to a significant hemorrhage, as seen in this patient with profuse upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatic artery: The hepatic artery primarily supplies the liver and is not typically involved in ulcers on the lesser curvature of the stomach.

 

Option C. Left gastroepiploic artery: The left gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach, making it less likely to be affected by ulcers on the lesser curvature.

 

Option D. Gastroduodenal artery: The gastroduodenal artery supplies the pylorus and the proximal duodenum and is less likely to be involved by an ulcer on the lesser curvature unless the ulcer is located at the pylorus or duodenal bulb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The left gastric artery, which runs along the lesser curvature, is at risk of being eroded by peptic ulcers in that location, leading to potential life-threatening hemorrhages.

choices.text: Autologous saphenous vein achieves superior patency rates to prosthetic materials, especially in femorodistal bypass.
The patency of PTFE grafts may be improved by interposition of a vein cuff at the proximal anastomosis.
Doppler ultrasound assessment is the method of choice for quality assurance of graft upon completion of the operative procedure.
In the absence of specific contraindications, aspirin should be prescribed for all patients with peripheral vascular disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the use of grafts in vascular surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The patency of PTFE grafts may be improved by interposition of a vein cuff at the proximal anastomosis.

 

This statement is true. Autologous saphenous vein grafts are known to achieve better patency rates than prosthetic materials, particularly in femorodistal bypasses, due to their biological compatibility and adaptability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The patency of PTFE grafts may be improved by interposition of a vein cuff at the proximal anastomosis: This is the incorrect statement. The patency of PTFE grafts may be improved by interposition of a vein cuff at the distal anastomosis, not the proximal anastomosis.

 

Option C. Doppler ultrasound assessment is the method of choice for quality assurance of graft upon completion of the operative procedure: Doppler ultrasound assessment is indeed the method of choice for postoperative quality assurance in vascular surgery because it noninvasively evaluates blood flow through the graft.

 

Option D. In the absence of specific contraindications, aspirin should be prescribed for all patients with peripheral vascular disease: Aspirin is recommended postoperatively for patients with peripheral vascular disease unless specific contraindications exist, due to its antiplatelet and antithrombotic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The patency of prosthetic vascular grafts, like PTFE, can be improved with a vein cuff, but it should be placed at the distal anastomosis for the most beneficial effect.
  • Doppler ultrasound is a key tool for postoperative assessment, and aspirin is a cornerstone of therapy in patients with peripheral vascular disease to improve graft patency and prevent thrombotic complications.

choices.text: Shake the inhaler well before use
Clean the inhaler after every use
Wait for 1 minute in between puffs

questions.text: A patient with bronchial asthma is prescribed 2 puffs from a metered dose inhaler containing budesonide. Which of the following should NOT be done?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clean the inhaler after every use

 

  • Cleaning the inhaler after every use is not typically necessary and is not usually recommended unless specifically instructed, as frequent cleaning can potentially affect the dosage and delivery mechanics of the inhaler.
  • Metered dose inhalers (MDIs) like those used for budesonide usually require less frequent cleaning, often just once a week or per the manufacturer's instructions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shake the inhaler well before use: Shaking the inhaler well before use is recommended for most MDIs to ensure the medication is well mixed and delivered effectively.

 

Option C. Wait for 1 minute in between puffs: Waiting for 1 minute between puffs is recommended to allow the first dose to settle and the second dose to be delivered more effectively.

 

Option D. Rinse mouth after every use: Rinsing the mouth after each use is particularly important with corticosteroid inhalers like budesonide to prevent oral thrush and reduce the risk of systemic absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While regular shaking and rinsing the mouth after use of inhaler are important for effective treatment and to minimize side effects, frequent cleaning of the inhaler device itself is generally not necessary and should be done according to specific guidelines to maintain device efficacy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has had severe abdominal pain for the past 2 days. Physical examination shows board-like rigidity of the abdominal muscles, making further examination difficult. There is no observable abdominal distention. The representative gross appearance of the disease process is shown in the figure. Which of the following is the mechanism most likely to produce this appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dysregulation of trypsinogen inactivation

 

  • The image provided suggests a pancreatic pathology, likely acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis with foci of white chalky necrosis, given the clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain and the gross appearance of the pancreas.
  • Acute pancreatitis is commonly associated with dysregulation of trypsinogen inactivation.
  • Normally, trypsinogen is activated to trypsin in the small intestine, but premature activation within the pancreas leads to autodigestion and inflammation, which is what can be seen in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CFTR gene mutation - Mutations in the CFTR gene are responsible for cystic fibrosis, which can lead to chronic pancreatitis due to thick secretions that block the pancreatic ducts. However, this does not typically lead to the acute process seen in the image.

 

Option B. Coxsackievirus B infection: This is associated with myocarditis and pericarditis, and while it can affect other organs, it is not a common cause of the acute pancreatitis depicted in the image.

 

Option D. K-RAS gene mutation: Mutations in the K-RAS gene are often seen in cancers, including pancreatic cancer, but would not cause the acute process indicated by the gross pathology in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the context of acute severe abdominal pain and the pathologic appearance of the pancreas suggesting pancreatitis, dysregulation of trypsinogen inactivation is the most likely mechanism of disease, leading to autodigestion of the pancreas and the clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man has had recurrent episodes of bloody diarrhea for five years and is currently on sulfasalazine treatment. He has experienced multiple disease flares that necessitate periodic steroid therapy to achieve remission. Considering his disease course, what is the most appropriate medication to add for maintenance therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Azathioprine

 

  • Azathioprine is an immunosuppressive medication often used for maintaining remission in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, particularly when they have a recurrent course despite treatment with aminosalicylates like sulfasalazine.
  • Azathioprine helps to reduce the need for corticosteroids and is effective for long-term maintenance therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is used in the treatment of Crohn's disease but is generally considered a second-line agent for those who do not tolerate or respond to thiopurines like azathioprine.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine may be used in severe, acute flare-ups of ulcerative colitis but is not typically used for long-term maintenance due to its side-effect profile.

 

Option D. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is not commonly used in the treatment of IBD due to its high toxicity and is more often reserved for severe, life-threatening vasculitis or autoimmune conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Azathioprine is an effective agent for maintaining remission in patients with frequent exacerbations who require corticosteroids for flare control.
  • Azathioprine reduces the dependence on steroids and helps prevent relapses.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of Crohn's disease presents with perianal discomfort and drainage. On examination, there is evidence of a high perianal fistula. Considering the patient’s sphincter involvement and the need to avoid incontinence, which of the following would be the most appropriate management strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Seton placement

 

  • Seton placement is appropriate for managing high fistula-in-ano, especially in patients with underlying inflammatory bowel disease like Crohn's.
  • Setons help maintain drainage and promote fibrosis without compromising sphincter integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate fistulotomy: Immediate fistulotomy might be contraindicated in high or complex fistulas, especially in patients with Crohn's disease, due to the risk of incontinence.

 

Option C. LIFT: LIFT is performed for intersphincteric fistula in ano, not high fistulas.

 

Option D. Lateral internal sphincterotomy: Lateral internal sphincterotomy is done for anal fissure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with Crohn’s disease presenting with fistula-in-ano, seton placement offers a sphincter-sparing option that allows for controlled drainage and fibrosis, thereby preserving continence while managing the fistula.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a long-standing history of asthma is referred to a pulmonologist, who decides to prescribe zileuton. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibits 5-lipoxygenase

 

  • Zileuton works by inhibiting 5-lipoxygenase, an enzyme that is crucial in the leukotriene pathway, which produces substances like leukotriene B4 and leukotriene D4 that contribute to inflammation, bronchoconstriction, and mucus production in asthma.
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, zileuton effectively reduces the production of leukotrienes, thus decreasing inflammation and asthma symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antagonize leukotriene D4 receptor: Antagonizing the leukotriene D4 receptor is the mechanism of action for leukotriene receptor antagonists (such as montelukast and zafirlukast), not zileuton.

 

Option C. Inhibits 5-lipoxygenase: Inhibiting phosphodiesterases is a mechanism of action of drugs like theophylline, which are used to treat asthma by a different pathway involving the increase of cAMP which helps in bronchodilation.

 

Option D. Stimulate β2 receptors: Stimulating β2 receptors is the mechanism of action of β2 agonists (such as albuterol and salmeterol), which are used for quick relief of asthma symptoms by directly causing bronchodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zileuton’s role as a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor distinguishes it in asthma management by targeting the leukotriene pathway, offering a therapeutic alternative especially useful in patients who may not fully respond to other asthma therapies.

choices.text: Arnold-Chiari II malformation

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with six months of speech difficulty, frequent dizziness, headaches, neck pain, deteriorating bladder and bowel control, sensory loss in the upper body, and muscle wasting in the neck and shoulders. MRI reveals cervical and thoracic spinal cord expansion with CSF in the central canal and brain abnormalities like the provided figure. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arnold-Chiari II malformation

 

  • The clinical presentation and MRI findings described are characteristic of a Chiari malformation, specifically the Arnold-Chiari II type.
  • This malformation involves the downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and sometimes the medulla through the foramen magnum.
  • This condition can cause a syringomyelia or hydromyelia, which can lead to the enlargement of the central canal of the spinal cord seen in the MRI, as well as the described muscle wasting and sensory loss due to damage of the nerve tracts.
  • Arnold-Chiari malformation can also be associated with myelomeningocele and other neural tube defects that might explain the variety of symptoms, including difficulties with bladder and bowel control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebral palsy: This is a group of permanent movement disorders that appear in early childhood and are not associated with the MRI findings described.

 

Option C. Dandy-Walker malformation: This involves a congenital malformation of the cerebellum and the fluid spaces around it. It is characterized by an enlargement of the fourth ventricle and a complete or partial absence of the cerebellar vermis. This condition does not match the MRI findings or symptoms described.

 

Option D. Holoprosencephaly: This is a failure of the brain to properly divide into the right and left hemispheres, which occurs during early pregnancy and is not consistent with the patient's age or the described MRI findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with signs and symptoms such as difficulty speaking, dizziness, falls, headache, neck pain, muscle wasting in the lower neck and shoulders, loss of pain and temperature sensation, and MRI findings showing enlargement of the central canal and cerebellar displacement, Arnold-Chiari II malformation should be considered the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of chronic sinusitis presents with hemoptysis. She has periorbital edema, and urinalysis reveals red blood cell casts. A CT scan of the chest has been conducted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Granulomatosis with angiitis

 

  • The combination of chronic sinusitis, hemoptysis, renal involvement (indicated by RBC casts in the urine), and a CT chest image suggestive of pulmonary nodules or cavities is characteristic of granulomatosis with angiitis, also known as Wegener's granulomatosis.
  • This condition is a type of vasculitis that affects small to medium-sized vessels and is associated with granulomatous inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endobronchial TB: Endobronchial TB could present with hemoptysis and abnormal chest findings, but it is less likely to cause chronic sinusitis or red blood cell casts in the urine, which are indicative of kidney involvement.

 

Option C. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa is another vasculitis that can cause multiple system involvements. However, it does not typically present with granulomas or involve the respiratory tract as prominently as granulomatosis with angiitis does.

 

Option D. Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis: Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is a rare lung disease that occurs almost exclusively in women and typically presents with cystic changes in the lungs on imaging. It does not cause sinusitis or red blood cell casts in the urine, and it usually leads to progressive dyspnea rather than hemoptysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Granulomatosis with angiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis) presents with the classic triad of upper respiratory tract involvement (chronic sinusitis), lower respiratory tract symptoms (hemoptysis), and renal impairment (red blood cell casts).
  • This systemic vasculitis often presents with multisystem involvement and requires immunosuppressive therapy for management.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS-P score of a patient brought into the ER with history of fall from a motorcycle. He is just making incomprehensible sounds, has a completely flexed posture and only opens his eyes to knuckle pressure. On examination, right pupil is unreactive to light:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

  • To calculate the GCS-P (Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils) score for the patient, we will assess the eye, verbal, and motor responses, and then adjust for pupil reactivity.
    1. Eye response: The patient opens eyes to knuckle pressure (pain), which scores a 2.
    2. Verbal response: The patient is making incomprehensible sounds, which scores a 2.
    3. Motor response: The patient has a completely flexed posture, which is consistent with decorticate posturing, which scores a 3.

 

Adding these together:

Eye Response + Verbal Response + Motor Response=2+2+3=7

Now, for the pupillary response:

One pupil is unreactive to light, which subtracts 1 from the GCS score.

GCS Score−Pupillary Score=7−1=6

The final GCS-P score is 6.

The correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils (GCS-P) is an extension of the GCS that includes the assessment of pupillary light response.
  • It is used to evaluate the severity of brain injuries.
  • The GCS-P score is derived by subtracting the pupillary score from the GCS score, providing a more comprehensive assessment of the patient's neurological status.

questions.text: Which of the following purgatives increases the fecal bulk due to their water-absorbing and retaining capacity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methyl cellulose

 

  • Methyl cellulose is a type of bulk-forming laxative that works by absorbing water and increasing the bulk of the stool, which stimulates bowel motility and facilitates the passage of stool.
  • This mechanism helps to soften the stool and is effective in managing constipation by enhancing the stool's size and moisture content.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lactulose: Lactulose is an osmotic laxative that works by drawing water into the bowel to soften stools and stimulate bowel movements, but it does not increase fecal bulk through water absorption and retention as bulk-forming agents do.

 

Option C. Liquid paraffin: Liquid paraffin is a lubricant laxative that coats the stool to help it pass more easily but does not increase fecal bulk.

 

Option D. Dioctyl sodium sulfosuccinate: Dioctyl sodium sulfosuccinate is a stool softener (surfactant laxative) that helps mix fatty substances into the stool to soften it, aiding in smoother bowel movements but not significantly increasing fecal bulk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bulk-forming laxatives like methyl cellulose are particularly beneficial for increasing fecal bulk and water content, making them ideal for long-term management of constipation without the risk of dependency or significant side effects.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man died suddenly after a week-long illness. He experienced chest pain, became increasingly dyspnoeic and nauseated, and lost consciousness multiple times. On the day of his death, he did not get up from his bed. External examination of the body by the medical examiner shows no evidence of trauma. The gross appearance of the chest cavity at autopsy with the pericardial sac opened as shown in the figure is most consistent with what underlying cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occlusive coronary atherosclerosis

 

  • The figure shows a massive hemopericardium with pericardial tamponade.
  • Rupture of a transmural myocardial infarction typically occurs 4 to 5 days after onset, when there is maximal necrosis before significant healing.
  • Ischemic heart disease occurs in patients of this age, and risk factors such as obesity, smoking, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia can play a role in its development.
  • The absence of trauma and the sudden onset of symptoms like chest pain, dyspnea, nausea, and loss of consciousness are highly suggestive of a cardiac cause of death, particularly myocardial infarction, which is most commonly caused by occlusive coronary atherosclerosis.
  • The week-long illness could indicate a prodromal period where there may have been increasing occlusion leading up to a complete blockage causing his death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marfan syndrome: While Marfan syndrome can lead to cardiac issues, such as aortic dissection, which can be fatal, it is a connective tissue disorder that is often associated with features not mentioned in the question, such as tall stature and limb elongation.

 

Option B. Disseminated tuberculosis: Disseminated tuberculosis can be fatal but would typically present with systemic symptoms over a longer duration and more commonly affect the lungs with evidence of granulomas or other characteristic changes, which were not noted here.

 

Option C. Scleroderma: Scleroderma can cause systemic fibrosis and affect multiple organs, including the heart. However, it tends to have a more chronic course, and the absence of skin findings or other systemic features makes this less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a relatively young patient presenting with sudden cardiac death without trauma, occlusive coronary atherosclerosis leading to myocardial infarction is the most likely cause, especially when considering the classic symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea before the loss of consciousness and death.

questions.text: A woman with a history of multiple miscarriages, deep vein thrombosis, low platelet count, and a recent myocardial infarction is being evaluated. What is the most appropriate diagnosis for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome

 

  • Primary anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and pregnancy complications, often with thrombocytopenia, which aligns with this patient's clinical presentation.
  • APS is defined by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies, which can lead to recurrent venous or arterial thrombosis and pregnancy-related complications such as recurrent miscarriages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catastrophic anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome: Catastrophic APS is a severe form of APS leading to multi-organ failure, which could be possible here given the recent MI; however, it is a rare condition and typically presents as a medical emergency.

 

Option C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP): TTP is characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, renal dysfunction, fever, and neurological symptoms but is less likely to be associated with recurrent miscarriages.

 

Option D. Protein C deficiency: Protein C deficiency is a hereditary thrombophilia that could cause deep vein thrombosis but is less likely to be associated with recurrent miscarriages or the broad spectrum of this patient's clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • APS should be suspected in young patients presenting with unexplained venous or arterial thrombosis, recurrent fetal loss, and thrombocytopenia, and the diagnosis is supported by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • It's important to distinguish APS from other thrombophilic disorders to guide appropriate long-term management, which typically includes anticoagulation therapy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with prostate cancer has a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan that reveals the tumor has extended beyond the prostatic capsule and involves the seminal vesicles. According to the TNM classification, Infiltration of Ca Prostate and seminal vesicles is categorised as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T3b

 

This is the correct answer. Involvement of the seminal vesicles by the tumor is categorized as T3b in the TNM classification of prostate cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T3a: This classification indicates extracapsular extension of the tumor without seminal vesicle invasion.

 

Option C. T3c: There is no T3c category in the TNM classification for prostate cancer.

 

Option D. T4a. This classification is used when the tumor has invaded adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as the bladder neck, external sphincter, or rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to understand the TNM staging system for prostate cancer.
  • T3b signifies that the cancer has spread to the seminal vesicles.
  • This staging is critical for determining the appropriate treatment plan and prognosis for prostate cancer patients.

choices.text: Continue the same antibiotic but at a higher dose
Remove amikacin and add a quinolone

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with ventilator-associated pneumonia is being treated with ceftriaxone and amikacin. Culture and sensitivity results indicate an ESBL (Extended Spectrum Beta-Lactamase) producing Klebsiella infection. What is the most appropriate next action?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Change over to imipenem

 

  • For infections caused by ESBL-producing bacteria such as Klebsiella species, carbapenems like imipenem are considered the treatment of choice due to their resistance to the beta-lactamase enzymes produced by these pathogens.
  • Imipenem has a broad spectrum of activity and is effective against many gram-negative bacteria including those that produce ESBL, making it suitable for severe infections like ventilator-associated pneumonia where resistant organisms are involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue the same antibiotic but at a higher dose: Continuing the same antibiotics, even at higher doses, is typically ineffective against ESBL-producing organisms because these enzymes can inactivate most beta-lactams.

 

Option B. Replace ceftriaxone with ceftazidime: Replacing ceftriaxone with ceftazidime is not advisable as both are third-generation cephalosporins and are generally ineffective against ESBL-producing organisms due to enzyme-mediated resistance.

 

Option C. Remove amikacin and add a quinolone: Removing amikacin and adding a quinolone may not be effective since ESBL-producing organisms often show resistance to multiple drug classes, including fluoroquinolones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Carbapenems like imipenem are often necessary due to their ability to resist degradation by beta-lactamase enzymes.

questions.text: A previously healthy, 22-year-old woman has had a low-grade fever for the past 2 weeks. On physical examination, her temperature is 37.7°C; there are no other remarkable findings. The gross appearance of the lung shown in the figure is representative of her disease. Which of the following studies is most likely to report a positive result?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tuberculin skin test

 

  • These findings represent the so-called Ghon (or primary) complex, consisting of a small subpleural granuloma with extensive hilar nodal caseating granulomas.
  • The Ghon complex is a feature of primary tuberculosis, which is most often a subclinical disease of younger individuals.
