  • Individuals who are immunocompromised, such as HIV-infected patients, do not mount a good granulomatous response and have more extensive poorly formed granulomas, dissemination of tuberculosis, or both.
  • A tuberculin skin test (also known as a PPD test) is used to determine if someone has developed an immune response to the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anticentromeric antibody: Typically associated with systemic sclerosis, not primarily a lung infection.

 

Option B. Antinuclear antibody: Often tested for in autoimmune diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus, not an acute infection.

 

Option C. HIV serologic test: While it's important to test for HIV in patients with tuberculosis, the lung pathology alone doesn't directly suggest HIV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a young adult presenting with a persistent low-grade fever and no significant findings except on the lungs, tuberculosis should be considered, and a tuberculin skin test is the appropriate study to report a positive result if the disease is present.

questions.text: Recurrent formation of a hypopyon in the eye and associated thrombophlebitis would be most characteristic of which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Behçet's syndrome

 

  • Behçet's syndrome is a systemic vasculitis that can cause recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and vascular problems such as thrombophlebitis.
  • The presence of hypopyon (a layer of white blood cells in the anterior chamber of the eye) is a classic sign of ocular involvement in Behçet's syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B27 associated uveitis: HLA B27 associated uveitis typically does not present with thrombophlebitis.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis can cause a variety of ocular problems, but recurrent hypopyon is not characteristic.

 

Option D. Herpes Zoster: Herpes Zoster can affect the eye, typically in the form of herpes zoster ophthalmicus, but it is not classically associated with recurrent hypopyon or thrombophlebitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Behçet's syndrome is a systemic disorder characterized by recurrent hypopyon and thrombophlebitis, among other systemic manifestations.

choices.text: Ciprofloxacin decreases the effect of theophylline

questions.text: Ciprofloxacin should not be given to an asthmatic using theophylline because:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ciprofloxacin inhibits theophylline metabolism

 

  • Ciprofloxacin is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 enzyme system, particularly CYP1A2, which is responsible for metabolizing theophylline.
  • When ciprofloxacin is administered with theophylline, it can lead to decreased clearance of theophylline from the body, resulting in increased blood levels of theophylline.
  • This can raise the risk of theophylline toxicity, which can manifest as cardiac arrhythmias, central nervous system stimulation, and other severe side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Theophylline inhibits ciprofloxacin metabolism: Theophylline does not significantly affect the metabolism of ciprofloxacin; this antibiotic's metabolism involves other pathways that theophylline does not notably influence.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin decreases the effect of theophylline: Ciprofloxacin does not decrease the effect of theophylline; rather, it increases theophylline's plasma concentration due to metabolic inhibition.

 

Option D. Theophylline induces metabolism of ciprofloxacin: Theophylline does not induce the metabolism of ciprofloxacin; it primarily undergoes metabolism through other cytochrome P450 enzymes that ciprofloxacin does not significantly induce.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The interaction between ciprofloxacin and theophylline, where ciprofloxacin inhibits the metabolism of theophylline, potentially leading to toxic levels.
  • Recognizing drug interactions, especially those involving cytochrome P450 enzymes, is crucial for preventing adverse effects and ensuring safe pharmacotherapy, particularly in patients with chronic conditions like asthma.

choices.text: Diffuse large B cell Lymphoma
B cell rich T cell lymphoma
Mediastinal rich B cell lymphoma

questions.text: A young boy came with dyspnea and was found to have a mediastinal mass. Which of the following is known to produce mediastinal lymphadenopathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T cell Lymphoblastic ALL

 

  • T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma/acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL/LBL) is known for its association with mediastinal masses, especially in children and young adults.
  • The thymus, located in the anterior mediastinum, is often involved, leading to significant mediastinal lymphadenopathy. This condition presents with symptoms like dyspnea, cough, and superior vena cava syndrome due to the mass effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse large B cell Lymphoma: While it can involve the mediastinum, it is more commonly associated with lymphadenopathy in other regions.

 

Option B. B cell rich T cell lymphoma: This is not a standard classification of lymphomas, and T-cell lymphomas typically, but not exclusively, involve the mediastinum.

 

Option C. Mediastinal rich B cell lymphoma: While primary mediastinal (thymic) large B-cell lymphoma is a distinct entity that presents with a mediastinal mass, T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma/ALL is more characteristically associated with mediastinal lymphadenopathy in younger patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma/acute lymphoblastic leukemia is commonly associated with the presence of a mediastinal mass and mediastinal lymphadenopathy in young patients, often leading to symptoms such as dyspnea due to the mass effect on the surrounding structures.

choices.text: Aprocitentan is indicated for the treatment of chronic heart failure, acting as a beta-blocker to reduce heart rate and decrease myocardial oxygen demand.
Aprocitentan is used for managing migraine headaches, functioning as a CGRP receptor antagonist to prevent the onset of migraine episodes.
Aprocitentan is approved for the treatment of resistant hypertension, where it serves as a dual endothelin receptor antagonist, reducing blood pressure by blocking the action of endothelin.
Aprocitentan is utilized in the treatment of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, acting as a DPP-4 inhibitor to improve glycemic control by increasing insulin secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the indication and mechanism of action of the drug Aprocitentan?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aprocitentan is approved for the treatment of resistant hypertension, where it serves as a dual endothelin receptor antagonist, reducing blood pressure by blocking the action of endothelin.

 

  • Aprocitentan works as a dual endothelin receptor antagonist, targeting the endothelin A and B receptors.
  • Endothelin is a potent vasoconstrictor peptide produced by the endothelial cells, and by blocking its receptors, aprocitentan helps reduce vasoconstriction and thereby lowers blood pressure.
  • This mechanism is particularly beneficial in the treatment of resistant hypertension, which is hypertension that remains uncontrolled despite the use of multiple antihypertensive medications.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Chronic heart failure, beta-blocker: This is incorrect. Aprocitentan is not a beta-blocker, nor is it indicated for chronic heart failure. Beta-blockers work by blocking the effects of adrenaline on the heart, reducing heart rate and force of contraction.

 

Option B. Migraine headaches, CGRP receptor antagonist: Incorrect. CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) receptor antagonists are used to prevent migraines but are unrelated to aprocitentan’s mechanism or indication.

 

Option D. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, DPP-4 inhibitor: Incorrect. DPP-4 inhibitors work by prolonging the action of incretin hormones, which increase insulin release. Aprocitentan does not function through this pathway and is not used for managing diabetes.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Aprocitentan is specifically indicated for the management of resistant hypertension through its action as a dual endothelin receptor antagonist.
  • This role involves the blocking of endothelin's effect on blood vessels, thereby helping to lower blood pressure in patients who have not responded adequately to other treatments.

questions.text: In patients diagnosed with polymyositis, the presence of which autoantibody is known to increase the risk of developing interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-Jo-1 antibody

 

  • Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are specific autoantibodies associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis and are a part of the anti-synthetase syndrome.
  • Patients with anti-Jo-1 antibodies are at an increased risk of interstitial lung disease, which can be a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-CCP antibody: Anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are most commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis and not typically linked to interstitial lung disease in the context of polymyositis.

 

Option B. Anti-ds DNA antibody: Anti-ds DNA (double-stranded DNA) antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and not specifically linked to interstitial lung disease in polymyositis.

 

Option C. Anti-cardiolipin antibody: Anti-cardiolipin antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome and are not directly linked to interstitial lung disease in the context of polymyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are strongly associated with interstitial lung disease in patients with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, forming part of the anti-synthetase syndrome.
  • The detection of these antibodies in patients with polymyositis is crucial for prognosis and management, as it may warrant close respiratory monitoring and aggressive therapy to manage lung involvement.
